<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The mass, in kilograms, of a block of cheese sold in a supermarket is denoted by the random variable \(M\). The masses of a random sample of 40 blocks are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 115, 678, 135]]<|/det|>
\[n = 40\qquad \Sigma m = 20.50\qquad \Sigma m^2 = 10.7280\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 146, 173]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 153, 734, 173]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 154, 920, 173]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 559, 615, 577]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Andy and Jessica are doing a survey about musical preferences. They plan to choose a representative sample of six students from the 256 students at their college.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Andy suggests that they go to the music building during the lunch hour and choose six students at random from the students who are there.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 547, 185]]<|/det|>
Give a reason why this method is unsatisfactory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 408, 143, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
Jessica decides to use another method. She numbers all the students in the college from 1 to 256. Then she uses her calculator and generates the following random numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 450, 771, 470]]<|/det|>
204393 162007 204028 587119 207395

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 477, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
From these numbers, she obtains six student numbers. The first three of her student numbers are 204, 162 and 7.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 523, 698, 542]]<|/det|>
Continue Jessica's method to obtain the next three student numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A certain kind of firework is supposed to last for 30 seconds, on average, after it is lit. An inspector suspects that the fireworks actually last a shorter time than this, on average. He takes a random sample of 100 fireworks of this kind. Each firework in the sample is lit and the time it lasts is noted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Give a reason why it is necessary to take a sample rather than testing all the fireworks of this kind.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 325, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
It is given that the population standard deviation of the times that fireworks of this kind last is 5 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 148, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 355, 821, 374]]<|/det|>
The mean time lasted by the 100 fireworks in the sample is found to be 29 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 386, 620, 405]]<|/det|>
Test the inspector's suspicion at the \(1\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 387, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
In a certain large document, typing errors occur at random and at a constant mean rate of 0.2 per page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that there are fewer than 3 typing errors in 10 randomly chosen pages. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 144, 920, 161]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
In the same document, formatting errors occur at random and at a constant mean rate of 0.3 per page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total number of typing and formatting errors in 20 randomly chosen pages is between 8 and 11 inclusive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
A machine is supposed to produce random digits. Bob thinks that the machine is not fair and that the probability of it producing the digit 0 is less than \(\frac{1}{10}\). In order to test his suspicion he notes the number of times the digit 0 occurs in 30 digits produced by the machine. He carries out a test at the \(10\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 153, 146, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 153, 522, 171]]<|/det|>
State suitable null and alternative hypotheses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 153, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 330, 148, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 330, 450, 349]]<|/det|>
Find the rejection region for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 330, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 735, 143, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 735, 462, 754]]<|/det|>
State the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 735, 920, 754]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 833, 92]]<|/det|>
It is now given that the machine actually produces a 0 once in every 40 digits, on average.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 148, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 468, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 735, 186, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 735, 591, 752]]<|/det|>
Explain the meaning of a Type II error in this context.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 735, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
